Key Arguments: The submission argues that the government is a major source of misinformation and disinformation, particularly in recent years.
It questions the government's ability to define and censor misinformation, suggesting that this leads to suppression of political diversity and free speech.
The submission highlights examples of government misinformation, particularly around COVID-19 and the 2020 US elections.
It argues that the proposed legislation is hypocritical, as it relies on a notion of objective truth that the government itself does not consistently uphold.
The submission suggests that censorship is a tool for political control and is anti-democratic.
Main Themes: Government as a source of misinformation
Censorship and its impact on democracy
The philosophical debate on truth and its implications for censorship
Examples of government misinformation (COVID-19, US elections)
Criticism of fact-checkers and media bias
Notable Quotes: Unfortunately, over the last three years Western governments have provided irrefutable evidence demonstrating that they indeed are the most guilty of peddling misinformation and disinformation.
This leads to a rank and dangerous hypocrisy.
The Federal Government shows no competency or credibility in dealing with the very concept of truth, taking an incoherent, opportunistic approach that bends it to its ideological objectives.
Political censorship spells the end of democracy.
